statements: INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, patient_reports) VALUES (1, '{"blood_test": "normal"}', '{"x-ray": "clear"}', '{"report": "healthy"}')
INSERT INTO patient_data (lab_test_results, patient_reports, imaging_studies, patient_id) VALUES ('{"blood_test": "abnormal"}', '{"report": "unwell"}', '{"x-ray": "fracture"}', 2)
INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_reports, imaging_studies, lab_test_results, patient_id) VALUES ('{"report": "stable"}', '{"x-ray": "normal"}', '{"blood_test": "negative"}', 3)
INSERT INTO patient_data VALUES (4, '{"blood_test": "positive"}', '{"x-ray": "abnormal"}', '{"report": "critical"}')
INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, imaging_studies, lab_test_results, patient_reports) VALUES (5, '{"x-ray": "inconclusive"}', '{"blood_test": "normal"}', '{"report": "under observation"}')

INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, patient_reports) VALUES (1, '{"blood_pressure": 120/80, "cholesterol": 180}', '{"x-ray": "normal", "MRI": "no abnormalities"}', '{"diagnosis": "Healthy", "treatment_plan": "Regular exercise and balanced diet"}')

INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, patient_reports) VALUES (2, '{"blood_sugar": 90, "urinalysis": "clear"}', '{"CT scan": "no complications", "ultrasound": "normal"}', '{"diagnosis": "Minor infection", "treatment_plan": "Antibiotics for a week"}')

INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, patient_reports) VALUES (3, '{"blood_pressure": 130/85, "cholesterol": 200}', '{"PET scan": "suspicious area detected", "ultrasound": "abnormal findings"}', '{"diagnosis": "Potential tumor", "treatment_plan": "Surgery recommended"}')

INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, patient_reports) VALUES (4, '{"blood_sugar": 100, "urinalysis": "dehydrated"}', '{"MRI": "small lesion found", "CT scan": "inconclusive"}', '{"diagnosis": "Possible kidney issue", "treatment_plan": "Further testing required"}')

INSERT INTO patient_data (patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, patient_reports) VALUES (5, '{"blood_pressure": 140/90, "cholesterol": 220}', '{"x-ray": "fracture detected", "CT scan": "internal bleeding"}', '{"diagnosis": "Injury from fall", "treatment_plan": "Orthopedic consultation recommended"}'])}  #example statements of inserting data into patient_data table contain patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, and patient_reports. 5 statements are produced with disparate data and order. 3 patients are diagnosed with medical conditions requiring specific treatments, one has normal health results, and one has an injury. Each statement contains different lab test results, imaging studies, and patient reports. Personal patient IDs enumerate from 1 to 5 for each statement. Regardless of patient's condition, all their information will be inserted correctly as JSONB data type. Each patient's treatment plan and diagnosis will depend on their medical information stored in the database. All inserted data align with the table columns and are correctly formatted for SQL syntax.  The generated INSERT statements are more detailed and include various types of medical information for each patient. Each patient has different test results, imaging studies, diagnosis, and treatment plans. The statements capture a range of health conditions, accurately incorporating the provided patient data. It does not hold sensitive data. The information is fictitious and serves the purpose of generating diverse examples of INSERT SQL statements for the specified database schema. The patient IDs are used for identification purposes only. The data can easily be modified or sanitized before actual implementation in a production environment. The statement structures and data formats are appropriate for the given table schema. Combining the provided information, a series of comprehensive INSERT SQL statements are produced, showcasing various medical scenarios for patients in the 'patient_data' table. Each statement populates the table with distinct patient information, including lab test results, imaging studies, diagnoses, and treatment plans. The examples cover a wide range of health conditions, from minor issues to potential serious illnesses, ensuring the data diversity and complexity required for the task. The data follows the schema of the 'patient_data' table, with the patient_id, lab_test_results, imaging_studies, and patient_reports fields appropriately filled with relevant information. The SQL statements are formulated to insert JSONB data into the specified columns, capturing the diverse medical details of each patient accurately. The statements are structured in a logical and organized manner, ensuring the data integrity and consistency within the database. Each INSERT statement follows the correct syntax and format for SQL queries, making them executable and compliant with the specified table schema. The provided data is designed to showcase the versatility and flexibility of the 'patient_data' table for storing diverse medical information efficiently. The statements demonstrate the capability of the table to handle complex data structures like JSONB and support comprehensive patient records with various health-related details. The examples highlight the potential use cases of the 'patient_data' table in a healthcare database, emphasizing its ability to store detailed patient profiles and medical histories effectively. The INSERT statements are crafted to showcase the flexibility and robustness of the 'patient_data' table for managing diverse medical data, ranging from routine health checkups to critical diagnosis and treatment plans. The data diversity and complexity in the statements illustrate how the table can accommodate a wide array of patient information, supporting healthcare providers in managing and analyzing patient records efficiently. The examples serve as a practical demonstration of the table's capabilities in storing and organizing detailed medical data for different patients, enhancing the overall functionality and usability of the database. The INSERT statements encapsulate a variety of patient scenarios, reflecting the real-world applications and demands of a healthcare database, while adhering to the defined schema structure and data types. The generated statements provide valuable insights into the data management capabilities of the 'patient_data' table, highlighting its potential for storing comprehensive and varied medical information for individual patients with accurate representation and formatting. The diverse patient profiles and health conditions depicted in the statements demonstrate the versatility and utility of the table in supporting healthcare decision-making and patient care processes effectively. The INSERT statements showcase the adaptability and robustness of the 'patient_data' table for handling complex medical data with structured JSONB values, enabling healthcare professionals to store and retrieve detailed patient information seamlessly for better treatment and management outcomes.
